posts.name: Prince M
posts.cooked:
The idea is that alliances utilize transmitters on their robots to communicate during a match, either using existing radios or new ones. This communication allows teams to share data such as pose information, enabling algorithms like pathfinding to avoid obstacles posed by opposing alliance robots. Near the end of a match, transmitting movement details (e.g., climbing, parking) instead of shouting could provide clearer instructions for the alliance's response.

As for FRC, even though it’s currently not legally allowed, there’s potential for them to consider making such communication methods official in the future or standardizing similar technologies across robots. Personally, I believe this innovation would enhance the competitiveness of FIRST Robotics Competition.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
R707 is what would currently prevent this.

That said, in a hypothetical future where inter-robot communication was allowed, I would suggest against using a separate transmitter/receiver system and instead utilize the existing wireless network. Currently, each team’s network (wireless from field to robot and wired from Driver Station to field) is segmented apart by VLANs. There’s nothing preventing FIRST from opening up communication across VLANs for the same alliance. Perhaps adding a single port between VLANs and integrating it into WPILib could facilitate communication/data sharing.

However, implementing such a solution requires teams to communicate and agree on a standardized data format. To ensure compatibility, it should ideally be built into WPILib, allowing teams to toggle its use based on their preferences. Teams could still dictate the types of data shared and the sources of those values, but the data structures must remain standardized.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

---

Fletch1373 mentioned that R707 prevents current functionality. However, it's possible to bypass both R707 and R706 using field radios alongside the Operator Console, especially when programming same functions creatively.

He pointed out that R904.A is often problematic if used in this workaround. To avoid becoming a CSA or FTA during such situations, which could require extensive communication with HQ, he emphasizes the importance of caution.

--- 

This version removes unnecessary HTML tags, condenses sentences, and maintains the core message while improving readability.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: I don't see how R904 (Operator console size/shape/etc.) comes into play here. R706/R707 clearly prohibit any form of network traffic except what we're accustomed to (Driver Station <- Robot via Field AP). If you're considering something but don't want to share it publicly, feel free to DM me. I'm definitely curious, because I don't see any options given the current rules.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: R706/R707 only prohibit wireless communication.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

Drive station with a separate local LAN switch and provide your alliance mates with a second Ethernet adapter for their PC. Isolate it to a specific subnet that won’t interfere with your robot network or the regular Ethernet adapter used by [Driver Station]. Even better, connect [Driver Station] first to [Field Management System], then establish your local LAN connections (don’t slow down the field; stay on top of setup and get started quickly).

You can then communicate between operators, share robot data, and link robots together by routing through [Driver Station].

Avoid wireless entirely and benefit from improved bandwidth and control compared to transmitting through the field network infrastructure.

Additionally, R706 specifically pertains to communication between operator consoles and the robot, not between robots themselves.

Each operator console controls its own robot through the arena network and listens on a secondary local network for echoed telemetry data.

Edit: You could also tether robots directly for communication, but unless it’s akin to a game like 2015, opposing alliances may attempt to disrupt the connection by unplugging wires or causing issues within the configured extension limits.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Semaphore flag detection is built into Limelight 5.

I have always believed there is significant potential for an alliance access level set at NT and also for establishing a general access level. These could utilize the same infrastructure, support wireless communication, and avoid transmitting data through other channels. The most crucial aspect is ensuring a substantial number of teams adhere to the required standards to make the system effective.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Significant numbers are needed in quals to be useful. Even just 3 or maybe 2 can have value in elims.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: R706 requires all signals to originate from the Operator Console and transmit through the ARENA Ethernet network to the Robot. R706 does not pertain to wireless communication or robot-to-operator communication specifically; it pertains to communication pathways involving the Robot and the Operator. Clarification indicates R706 involves specific communication protocols rather than general robot communication.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: You agree that two drive coaches could talk to each other during a match without violating R706.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Removing all HTML tags and unnecessary elements while preserving the original meaning, here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

---

The definition of "signal" and "originate" can vary, but the signal (such as a packet) sent to the ROBOT still originates from its respective Driver Station, even though we generate this signal based on information other than direct human input. It’s generally agreed that transmitting a camera stream from the robot to the Driver Station, performing image processing on the Driver Station side, and then sending a signal back to the robot based on that operation is permissible outside of the G402 restrictions.

Another alternative involves using the visual spectrum: one Driver Station could display a QR code for another Driver Station’s camera to scan. Notably, R905 doesn’t explicitly mention vision as an exception, only motion control using a Kinect. Perhaps one Driver Station waves a flag while the other uses a Kinect to detect it. In prior years, Driver Stations utilized their vision systems to send information to the robot, such as how the 254 team implemented it during Power Up. It’s unclear if this practice was intentional.

--- 

This version removes all HTML tags, corrects minor grammatical issues, and ensures the text flows naturally while maintaining its technical accuracy.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Yes, I concur that it serves as an exception when adhering strictly to the letter of the law. Considering the rule's title, "Don't bypass the ARENA network," it's reasonable to interpret this as pertaining to electrical signals rather than other types of signals.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If we asked the QA team, would they be able to provide a useful answer, or would we receive a 'We can’t provide input on a hypothetical concept' type answer?

I’d like to understand the boundary. If an IP camera captures images via a Driver Station (a system for monitoring and managing cameras) linked to a Robot Control System, and those images are used to control a robot, while the laptop is connected to a separate camera outside the arena’s control—potentially on a different subnet—it still works legally if any signals sent to the robot only go through the Driver Station and follow established protocols. The concern isn’t about the arena being involved, but rather adding extra systems (like hard-line Ethernet with TCP/IP) might introduce delays due to their latency compared to more reliable methods such as serial communication or direct HID keyboards remapped to joysticks. These alternative setups don’t require the arena’s involvement and could increase processing time unnecessarily.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: Drive station with a separate local LAN switch and provide your alliance mates with a second Ethernet adapter for their PC. I don't see how R904 (Operator console size/shape/etc) comes into play here. Who’s operator console is the switch and associated cabling a part of, and how does that affect the size of their operator console?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: The USB cable connecting our controller to the laptop’s USB hub is longer than 5 feet, and despite that, it was allowed during matches whenever the cabling length was the issue... Perhaps the driver will have to hold the switch to make it legally compliant.

posts.cooked:
Certainly! Here's a step-by-step explanation of how the text was cleaned up: ### Step 1: Remove HTML Tags - The original text enclosed in `

` tags was removed to isolate the content. ### Step 2: Simplify Language - "States” was replaced with "rule" for brevity. - "Any items" was rephrased to "items" to maintain conciseness. - "Held or worn by" was simplified to "worn by" for clarity. ### Step 3: Adjust Grammar and Flow - "DRIVERS" became "drivers" for consistency. - "MATCH" was pluralized to "matches" to align with common usage. - "Usually" was used instead of "any" to provide a smoother transition. ### Step 4: Ensure Single Paragraph - The final result is a concise, single-sentence paragraph without line breaks. ### Final Output: **"R904B rule excludes items usually worn by drivers during matches."** This approach minimizes changes while enhancing clarity and grammatical accuracy.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: If the drivers on both teams hold onto the Ethernet cable, rules lawyering is fun.

posts.name: Daniel G
posts.cooked:
The OPERATOR CONSOLE is defined as the set of components and mechanisms used by drivers and human players to relay commands to the robot. This raises the question: does the neighboring operator console, which communicates with a team’s operator console, become part of that team’s defined operator console? Drivers use information produced by the system to control the robot, and dashboards displaying a command interface are integral to the operator console because drivers utilize them.

While a more restrictive definition would include only components and mechanisms specifically designed for controlling the robot, such as a driver’s laptop, the term “use” likely encompasses indirect uses. Therefore, it may be reasonable to include items like screens or trays as part of the operator console.

However, if drivers on both teams hold onto an Ethernet cable, their computing devices can simply be used to send communication. This reduces the complexity of the issue, focusing on length rather than depth. 

If we project a hologram extending beyond 6 feet and 6 inches, it could theoretically be included, though whether such components are considered intangible requires clarification.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: the field reset life chose me (6201M, 3419A)

posts.name: Joe Johnson
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up text, preserving the original meaning while adhering to standard grammar and punctuation:

---

I don’t want to hijack the thread but I think FIRST could take the next logical step of having the robots form an alliance where they can publish information to each other. I believe there could be established standards for message contents and formatting, such as defining robot poses and velocities, and possibly enabling communication of planned pathways.

I don’t think implementing these changes in the first year would enhance the capabilities of robots but over two or three years, we can expect to see many innovative behaviors that aren’t possible today.

---

data.title: Is it legal to have robot-to-robot communication?
